---
title: 'The real options to shutdown, startup, and abandon: U.S. electricity industry
  evidence'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-Y5679VQ3" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Fleten, S.-E., Haugom, E., &#38; Ullrich, C. J. (2017). <div id="csl-bib-meta-Y5679VQ3" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-Y5679VQ3" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Fleten et al. conducted a study on the U.S. electricity industry, focusing on decisions to shut down, start up, or abandon power generators. They analyzed data from 1121 generators between 2001 and 2009. The study found that uncertainty about profits and regulations makes it less likely for companies to shut down existing generators. Regulatory uncertainty also reduces the likelihood of starting new generators, while uncertainty about cash flow actually increases the chances of starting up new, especially large, generators. These findings are important because they show how financial and regulatory uncertainties influence major decisions in the energy sector, affecting the stability and development of electricity production.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-Y5679VQ3" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Electricity Industry, Shutdown, Startup, Abandonment, Cash Flow Uncertainty, Regulatory Uncertainty
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-Y5679VQ3" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The purpose of this paper is to examine empirically the partially irreversible decisions to shutdown, startup, and abandon existing production assets under cash flow uncertainty and regulatory uncertainty. We use detailed information for 1121 individual electric power generators located in the U.S. for the period 2001–2009 and find strong evidence of real options effects. We find that both profitability uncertainty and regulatory uncertainty decrease the probability of shutdown. Regulatory uncertainty also decreases the probability of startup, but we find that cash flow uncertainty increases the probability of startup, especially for large generators.
  </article>
